large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The Very Impatient Caterpillar

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build alphabet knowledge, encourage physical movement, and introduce new vocabulary (twirl).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question: Why is the caterpillar impatient?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, calling attention to the humor and using the caterpillar’s questions to inform readers.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation; Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Use information to describe; Use information to categorize.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Understand and use academic language.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Assess alphabet and phonological knowledge by challenging children to name letters and their sounds in a timed competition.
Encourage teamwork.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find another book about science?
Can you pretend to be a caterpillar?
Can you draw a caterpillar? How many legs does your caterpillar have?
Can you write a story about being a caterpillar and changing into a butterfly?
Can you make the impatient caterpillar out of these materials?
Can you find words in Fox Can Fix It that have the letter x in them? Can you read them?
Can you build a caterpillar? Don’t forget the legs and antennae!

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The Very Impatient Caterpillar

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice the show self-awareness Mind Builder and introduce new vocabulary (I can, trying).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Very Impatient Caterpillar.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Understand and use academic language.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Connect to the book by reminding children about the impatient caterpillar.
Challenge children to practice patience and self-regulation through a game of freeze dance.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What can the character in your book be proud of?
Can you pretend to build a chrysalis? It’s metamorphosis time!
Can you use the hand lens to look at some of the butterfly things we have in the classroom?
Write about something you’re proud of.
Can you make a chrysalis out of these materials?
Can you find the words that start with the letter Z in Zebra Zooms? Can you read the words?
Can you build a special room for butterflies in a zoo? How will you keep the butterflies from flying away?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach. Copyright © 2019 by Ross Burach. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The Very Impatient Caterpillar

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Smart Conclusion and introduce new vocabulary (patient).
Start Story Time by revisiting The Very Impatient Caterpillar and asking the guiding question: How do we know the caterpillar is impatient?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast; Make predictions; Make inferences.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Think symbolically.
Understand and use academic language.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Practice sequencing book events based on pictorial clues.
Allow children to share feelings about funny moments from the text, using descriptive language.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is this story like The Very Impatient Caterpillar?
Can you pretend to wait in a chrysalis like the impatient caterpillar does?
How many activities can you name that the caterpillar does in the chrysalis?
Can you write the steps of the caterpillar’s metamorphosis?
Can you create a butterfly out of these materials?
Can you write the letter x?
Can you use blocks to build structures that look like butterfly wings?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach. Copyright © 2019 by Ross Burach. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What We Have Learned

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The Very Impatient Caterpillar

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about teamwork, and introduce vocabulary (investigate, discover).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts The Very Impatient Caterpillar and What We Have Learned.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: How have we changed?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Use information to describe; Use information to categorize; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Understand and use academic language.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Have children think about how they have grown and learned.
Allow them to paint pictures of what they’ve learned.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find something in your book that’s something that we’ve learned about this year?
Can you act out your favorite lesson from this year?
Can you count how many things we’ve learned about this year? What did we learn?
Can you write about your favorite lesson this year?
Can you make a character from one of our books using clay?
Can you write the letter Z?
Can you build a place from one of the books we read this year?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach. Copyright © 2019 by Ross Burach. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: The Very Impatient Caterpillar

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce children to new vocabulary (transform).
Start Story Time by revisiting The Very Impatient Caterpillar and asking, How are you like the impatient caterpillar?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Write for different purposes.
Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books; Share and repeat the details in a text.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Understand and use academic language.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: When have you had to be patient this year?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book that has a character who’s changing?
Can you pretend to be an impatient butterfly migrating with the other butterflies?
Can you draw a butterfly? How many wings does your butterfly have?
Can you write about a time where you grew and changed?
Can you use pipe cleaners and tissue to make a butterfly?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to your friend?
Can you build the impatient caterpillar’s chrysalis?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Very Impatient Caterpillar by Ross Burach. Copyright © 2019 by Ross Burach. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name at least 20 upper and at least 20 lower case letters in the language of instruction.
Produce at least 20 distinct sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Think symbolically.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Produce at least 20 distinct sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize and blend spoken phonemes into one syllable words with pictorial support.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Combine more than one idea using complex sentences.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
